sen.j: 源 雅実（みなもと の まさざね 康平元年（1058年） - 大治2年2月15日 (旧暦)（1127年3月29日））は、平安時代後期の村上源氏の公卿。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Masazane (1058 - March 29, 1127 (February 15, 1127 by the old calendar)) was a noble of the Murakami Genji court during the latter years of the Heian Period.
FUJIWARA no Masazane (1058 - March 29, 1127 (February 15, 1127 by the old calendar)) was a noble of the Murakami Genji court during the latter years of the Heian Period.
MINAMOATO no Masazane (1058 - April 5, 1127 (February 15, 1127 by the old calendar)) was a noble of the Murakami Genji court during the latter years of the Heian Period.

sen.j: 源顕房の長男。
sen.e: He was the first son of MINAMOTO no Akifusa.
He was the first son of MINAMOTO no Akifusa.
He was the first son of MINAMOTO no Akifusa.

sen.j: 久我家の祖とされる。
sen.e: He is known to be the founder of the Koga family.
He is famous for being the founder of the Koga family.
He is considered the founder of the Koga family.
sen.cmt: 有名という意味ではないので、famous forは使わず表現しました。

sen.j: 源氏初の太政大臣まで出世したほか、舞楽や文学に長じた文化人としても名を残す。
sen.e: He was the first of the Minamoto clan to successfully reach the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister) and he was also famous as a man of culture with knowledge and skill in court dance, music and literature.

He was the first of the Minamoto clan to successfully reach the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister), and he was also famous as a man of culture with knowledge and skill in court dance, music, and literature.

He was the first of the Minamoto clan to successfully reach the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister), and he was also famous as a man of culture with knowledge and skill in court dance, music, and literature.

sen.j: 「久我相国記」を記す。
sen.e: He wrote the "Koganosho Kokki."
He wrote "Koganosho Kokki."
He wrote "Koganosho Kokki."

sen.j: 久我太政大臣と号した。
sen.e: He was called Koganodaijodaijin (Grand Minister Koga).
He was called Koganodaijodaijin (Grand Minister Koga).
He was called Koganodaijodaijin (Grand Minister Koga).

sen.j: 治暦2年（1066年）に童殿上（貴族の子弟が殿上で見習いの奉仕をすること）を許される。
sen.e: In 1066, he was given permission for Warawa Tenjo (children of aristocratic families becoming apprentices and serving in the palace).
In 1066, he was given permission for Warawa Tenjo (children of aristocratic families becoming apprentices and serving in the palace).
In 1066, he was given permission for Warawa Tenjo (children of aristocratic families becoming apprentices and serving in the palace).

sen.j: 翌年の治暦3年10月に後冷泉天皇の御前で胡飲酒を舞い、御衣を賜ったことは後年長く語り伝えられた。
sen.e: The story of Masazane dancing the Konju for Emperor Gorizen and being presented with an imperial garment in October of 1067 has been told for generations.
The story of Masazane dancing the Konju for Emperor Gorizen and being presented with an imperial garment in October of 1067 has been told for generations.
The story of Masazane dancing the Konju for Emperor Goreizei and being presented with an imperial garment in November of 1067 has been told for generations.

sen.j: 治暦4年に従五位下に叙され、侍従・近衛府・右近権中将などを経て、承保2年（1075年）に白河天皇の蔵人頭に補任される。
sen.e: In 1068, he was made Jogoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and was appointed to positions such as Jiju (Chamberlain), Kokonoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Ukongon Chusho (Provincial Guard of the right), and was appointed as Kuroudo-no To (Emperor's personal secretary) to Emperor Shirakawa in 1075.

In 1068, he was made Jogoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and subsequently was appointed to positions such as Jiju (Chamberlain), Kokonoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards), and Ukongon Chusho (Provincial Guard of the right), and in 1075 was appointed Kuroudo-no To (Emperor's personal secretary) to Emperor Shirakawa.

In 1068, he was made Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and subsequently was appointed to positions such as Jiju (Chamberlain), Konoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards), and Ukongon Chusho (Provincial Guard of the right), and in 1075 was appointed Kuroudo-no To (Emperor's personal secretary) to Emperor Shirakawa.

sen.j: 承暦元年（1077年）従三位に昇進し、さらに同年12月3日に参議に任ぜられる。
sen.e: He was promoted to Jusani (Junior Third Rank) in 1077 and appointed Sangi (Councillor) on December 3rd of the same year.
He was promoted to Jusani (Junior Third Rank) in 1077 and appointed Sangi (Councillor) on December 3rd of the same year.
He was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1077 and appointed Sangi (Councillor) on December 26th of the same year.

sen.j: その後、権中納言・権大納言を経て、康和2年（1100年）内大臣に任ぜられる。
sen.e: Thereafter, he was appointed successively as Gon-chunagon (Provisional Middle Councillor), Gon-dainagon (Provisional Major Councillor), and in 1100, he was appointed as Naidaiji (Minister of the Interior).

Thereafter, he was appointed successively as Gon-chunagon (Provisional Middle Councillor), Gon-dainagon (Provisional Major Councillor), and in 1100, he was appointed as Naidaiji (Minister of the Interior).

Thereafter, he was appointed successively as Gon-chunagon (Provisional Middle Councillor), Gon-dainagon (Provisional Major Councillor), and in 1100, he was appointed as Naidaiji (Minister of the Interior).

sen.j: 永久3年（1115年）右大臣になり、保安3年（1122年）に太政大臣に昇った。
sen.e: In 1115, he became Udaijin (Minister of the right), reaching the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister) in 1122.
In 1115, he became Udaijin (Minister of the right), reaching the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister) in 1122.
In 1115, he became Udaijin (Minister of the right), reaching the position of Daijo Daijin (Grand Minister) in 1122.

sen.j: これは源氏の太政大臣補任の初例である。
sen.e: This was the first of the Minamoto clan to be appointed to the position of Daijo Daijin.
This made Masazane the first of the Minamoto clan to be appointed to the position of Daijo Daijin.
This made Masazane the first of the Minamoto clan to be appointed to the position of Daijo Daijin.

sen.j: しかし天治元年（1124年）病になったため、同年7月7日出家して法名を蓮覚とした。
sen.e: In 1124, he became ill, which made him decide to enter the priesthood on July 7, under the posthumous Buddhist name of Renkaku.
In 1124, he became ill, which made him decide to enter the priesthood on July 7, under the posthumous Buddhist name of Renkaku.
In 1124, he became ill, which made him decide to enter the priesthood on August 25, under the posthumous Buddhist name of Renkaku.

sen.j: 大治2年2月15日、69歳で薨去。
sen.e: On February 15, 1127, he died at the age of 69.
On February 15, 1127, he died at the age of 69.
On April 5, 1127, he died at the age of 69.

sen.j: 彼の薨去の際、同時代の人は「現世の昇進すでに万人を超え、入滅の時釈尊と同日なり、誠に是れ現当二世相叶ふ人か」（『中右記』）などと評していることからも、当時の雅実の名声の高さが伺える。
sen.e: When Masazane died, people of the period said; "Promoted to the highest rank in this world, and having died on the same date as Buddha, he may be a person who will reach the top of both worlds." ('Chuyuki (The Court Diary)'), which is an indication of Masazane's fame.

When Masazane died, people of the period said; "Promoted to the highest rank in this world, and having died on the same date as Buddha, he may be a person who will reach the top of both worlds." ('Chuyuki (The Court Diary)'), which is an indication of Masazane's fame.

When Masazane died, people of the period said; "Promoted to the highest rank in this world, and having died on the same date as Buddha, he may be a person who will reach the top of both worlds." ('Chuyuki' (The Court Diary)), which is an indication of Masazane's fame.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置

sen.j: 同年2月17日、遺体は久我（山城国愛宕郡久我）の山荘に移され、2月23日に久我の西辺に葬られた。
sen.e: On February 17th, his body was transferred to a mountain retreat in Kuga (Kuga, Otagi District, Yamashiro Province) and was buried in the western section of Kuga on February 23rd.
On February 17th, his body was transferred to a mountain retreat in Kuga (Kuga, Otagi District, Yamashiro Province), and on February 23rd it was buried in the western section of Kuga.
On April 7, his body was transferred to a mountain retreat in Kuga (Kuga, Otagi District, Yamashiro Province), and on April 13 it was buried in the western section of Kuga.

sen.j: 雅実は舞楽に優れ、秘曲『胡飲酒』を伝える楽家の多資忠が変死したとき、堀河天皇が『胡飲酒』を伝受していた雅実に命じて多忠方（資忠の子）に伝えさせた話は名高い。
sen.e: Masazane possessed outstanding skill in court dance and music, and there is a famous story that told that when Suketada ONO, who was supposed to pass down the court dance, Konju, died unnaturally, Emperor Horikawa ordered Masazane to teach the dance to Tadataka ONO (Suketada's son).

Masazane possessed outstanding skill in court dance and music, and there is a famous story that upon the unnatural death of Suketada ONO, who was supposed to pass down the court dance, Konju, Emperor Horikawa ordered Masazane to teach the dance to Tadataka ONO (Suketada's son).

Masazane possessed outstanding skill in court dance and music, and there is a famous story that upon the unnatural death of Suketada ONO, who was supposed to pass down the court dance, Konju, Emperor Horikawa ordered Masazane to teach the dance to Tadataka ONO (Suketada's son).
